title: Virginia Ham Biscuits
ingredients: Milk as needed, 3 to 4 tablespoons per cup of Mrs. Booth’s Biscuit Mix
Melted unsalted butter; or, milk for brushing the tops of the biscuits
1¼ to 1½ pounds of Virginia ham, very thinly sliced
instructions: Preheat the oven to 425° F. and grease or use spray oil, such as Pam®, two large baking sheets.
If you are going to use melted butter to brush the top of the biscuits then before starting melt 4 to 6 tablespoons of butter in a small heat-proof container and set it aside.

In a large mixing bowl, place the biscuit mix.  Using a fork, stir in enough milk to make soft, but not sticky, dough, approximately 3 to 4 tablespoons of milk per cup of mix.  Knead on a lightly floured work surface 5 or 6 times; or, until the dough is smooth and elastic.

With a rolling pin, roll the dough out to ¼-inch thickness, than fold over so that the biscuits will open easily when baked.  With a biscuit cutter, cut out biscuit rounds that are 1½ to 2 inches in diameter (smaller for cocktail size biscuits) and arrange them on the baking sheets.  Brush the tops of the biscuits with the melted butter; or, with milk.
Bake the biscuits for 7 to 10 minutes; or, until they are golden brown.
Open the biscuits and place some ham inside.
Yield:  Makes 40 regular biscuits; or, approximately 70 cocktail biscuits.

Source:  The Colonial Williamsburg Tavern Cookbook, by The Colonial Williamsburg Foundation, Recipes Developed by John R. Gonzales, Edited by Charles Pierce, Clarkson Potter/Publishers, New York, © 2001 by The Colonial Williamsburg Foundation.
